Extending LavaStorm¶

LavaStorm can be extended easily by subclassing the Profile class. Once you create your own class, set the class attribute sub_command_name and sub_command_help. The former defines the name of the profile argument, and should be a single word, short, and describe the profile. The second is a verbose help field that explains something about that profile, this will be displayed when the LavaStorm is called with the –help argument.

Generally, you only need to re-implement one other method: create_jobs(). This method must decide how many jobs are needed and when they should be submitted to the scheduler. Once put in the submit_queue, all other operations are automatic.

Job Creation Process¶

Jobs are put in the submit_queue by appending a dictionary with two keys, start_time, a datetime object set to a date before which the job should not be submitted to the cluster. The second key, job, is a dictionary of arguments that should be passed to the scheduler to execute the job. There are helper functions that will populate the data based on the range supplied by the user.:

job_data = {
            'start_time': start_time,
            'job': {
                'command': cmd,
                'requested_slots': self.get_num_processors(),
                'project_name': self.get_project_name(),
                'queue_name': self.get_queue_name(),
                'num_tasks': self.get_num_tasks(),
            },
        }

self.submit_queue.append(job_data)

Process API¶

Class Attributes¶

Profile.sub_command_name = 'Not Defined'¶
Profile.sub_command_help = 'Not Defined'¶

Helper Attributes¶

lavaStorm.Profile.total_submitted_jobs¶

The total number of jobs that have been submitted to the cluster.

lavaStorm.Profile.total_active_jobs = 0

The total number of active jobs that are on the cluster. This does not include jobs that are waiting to be submitted.

lavaStorm.Profile.total_finished_jobs = 0

The total number of jobs that have finished, this includes jobs that have failed or killed tasks.

lavaStorm.Profile.total_task_count = 0

The total number of tasks for all jobs.

lavaStorm.Profile.pending_task_count = 0

The total number of tasks that have been submitted into the cluster and are in a pending state.

lavaStorm.Profile.running_task_count = 0

The total number of tasks that are currently executing on the cluster.

lavaStorm.Profile.killed_task_count = 0

The total number of tasks that have been killed.

lavaStorm.Profile.completed_task_count = 0

The total number of tasks that have completed successfully.

lavaStorm.Profile.failed_task_count = 0

The total number of tasks that have failed.

Helper Methods¶

The following methods simplify creating job parameters and making decisions about submitting new jobs.

Profile.is_active()[source]¶

Returns true if the current time is inside the range of times this profile is active. If there are no active ‘office hours’ then always returns true.

Returns:True if the current profile is ‘in the office’
Profile.get_queue_name()[source]¶

Gets a random queue to submit jobs to, if no queue exists to chose from, returns None.

Returns:Queue name to submit job to, or None if no queues defined.
Profile.get_project_name()[source]¶

Gets a random project to submit jobs to, if no project exists to chose from, returns None.

Returns:Project name to submit job to, or None if no projects defined.
Profile.get_num_tasks()[source]¶

Gets the number of tasks for the job.

Returns:randint between min and max tasks per job.
Profile.get_num_processors()[source]¶

Returns the number of processors that should be used, uses a random number between min and max number of permitted processors.

Returns:num_processors - integer
Profile.get_runtime_seconds()[source]¶

Gets the number of seconds a job should run for. Used when creating a job to find the runtime that the job should run for.

Returns:runtime_seconds - the job runtime in seconds as an integer.
Profile.get_observation_time()[source]¶

Returns the number of seconds used to ‘Observe’ the results of the previous jobs. This simulates the user reviewing their work, prior to submitting a new job.

Returns:observation_time as TimeDelta
Profile.get_next_start_time()[source]¶

Returns a datetime object when the job should next start.

Returns:datetime object when job should start
Profile.create_job_command()[source]¶

Creates the command to run

Returns:cmd that will be executed as part of the job.

Core Methods¶

The following methods form the core, and can be overridden as required. Usually only add_arguments and create_jobs will need to be modified.

classmethod Profile.add_arguments(sub_parser)[source]¶

Adds any command line arguments needed by the profile. Arguments must not be positional arguments, and should where possible set default values. Must not return any value.

Parameters:sub_parser – Sub parser object that arguments should be added to.
Returns:None
Profile.create_jobs()[source]¶
Profile.start_job(num_tasks=1, **kwargs)[source]¶

Starts a new job, right now, using the job scheduler.

Parameters:
  • num_tasks – Number of tasks contained by job
  • kwargs – Dictionary containing arguments to be passed to the submit function.
Returns:

None
Profile.start_jobs()[source]¶

Iterates through the submit_queue, checks it the current time is on or after the earliest time to submit the job. If that is the case, then the job is submitted using start_job(). If it isnt, it is left in the queue.

Returns:None
Profile.get_job(job_id, array_index)[source]¶

Gets a job object for the job.

Parameters:
  • job_id – job_id of job to get
  • array_index – array_index of job to get
Returns:

Job object
Profile.get_jobs(job_id)[source]¶

Gets all tasks for specified job id

Parameters:job_id – Id of jot
Returns:list of job objects
Return type:list
Profile.process_running_jobs()[source]¶

Scans all job ids associated with this profile, and moves them into the associated list for pending, running, complete, killed, and failed jobs.

Returns:None
Profile.run()[source]¶

Called by the main loop periodically, manage jobs should create, start, stop, and kill processes as required.

Returns:None
Profile.start_jobs()[source]

Iterates through the submit_queue, checks it the current time is on or after the earliest time to submit the job. If that is the case, then the job is submitted using start_job(). If it isnt, it is left in the queue.

Returns:None
Profile.kill_all_jobs()[source]¶

Finds all jobs that are active, and tells the scheduler to kill them.

Returns:None
